text:
Rockefeller Plaza (center foreground), west side, from West 49th (left) to West 50th Streets (right), showing under construction the 70-story R.C.A. Building, within the Rockefeller Center development. The tall building on the right is the 31-story R.K.O. Building, facing on Sixth Ave., from West 50th to West 51st Streets, and preceding it is the International Music Hall, the largest and most magnificent motion picture theatre in the world. On the left is shown the Center Theatre, at the S.E. corner of West 49th Street. Also shown is a general view westward of the surrounding area with the Hudson River and the New Jersey shore line visible in the background.

August 29, 1932.

Wurtz Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
(1) Rockefeller Plaza, between West 49th and 50th Streets, as seen from the Empire Trust Building (No. 580 Fifth Ave.), and showing the new Rockefeller Center development. Steel structure is the future R.C.A. Building. Where the excavation is, the Plaza, Fountain, British and French Buildings stand to-day (1937).

June 8, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A view slightly eastward to Fifth Ave. Shown in the foreground, is the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas. Other prominent structure is the then new Goelet Building (608 Fifth Ave., at the S.W. corner of West 49th Street).

June 8, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 1, but at a later date. This view also shows further demolition north of 50th to 51st Streets.

May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
Rockefeller Plaza, east side, between West 49th and 50th Streets. Shown at the northern half of this block front, is the completed British Empire Building. On the extreme right, appears La Maison Francaise (French Building).

May 15, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
(1) Rockefeller Plaza, south from West 51st to 49th Streets. Shown under construction, is the new (opened March 1937) 45-story office building on the south side of 49th Street, west of Fifth Ave. At the completion of this building, this thoroughfare (Rockefeller Plaza) will extend to 48th Street.
November 23, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, slightly later. This building was completed in about 3 months. A major feat, even for this new development.
December 28, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street

text:
(1) Rockefeller Plaza, south from West 51st to 49th Streets. Shown under construction, is the new (opened March 1937) 45-story office building on the south side of 49th Street, west of Fifth Ave. At the completion of this building, this thoroughfare (Rockefeller Plaza) will extend to 48th Street.
November 23, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, slightly later. This building was completed in about 3 months. A major feat, even for this new development.
December 28, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street

text:
(1)
Rockefeller Plaza (left where men are standing), east side, between West 49th and West 50th Streets (within Rockefeller Center), showing the Prometheus Fountain and part of the open-air café at the western extremity of the Sunken Plaza, which is approachable from Fifth Ave. through the Promenade. The statue created by one of America's greatest living sculptors, Paul Manship, shows the flying Prometheus with the life giving fire in his right hand. It is in gilded bronze and stands in the midst of a granite basin.

August 24, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, another view.

August 24, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
Rockefeller Plaza, west side, north from W. 49th Street (foreground), showing the new Associated Press Building under construction on the 50th -51st Street block front. An announcement of this project was carried in the New York Times of January 19, 1938. The photographer is viewing northwestward across the sunken Promethian fountain and shows partially on the edges the 70 storied R.C.A. Building (left) and the International Building (right).

July 16, 1938.

P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
Rockefeller Plaza, west side, from W. 49th to 50th Street. This view shows the southerly exposure (W. 49th Street side) of the 70-storied R. C. A. Building. Rockefeller Plaza would be on the right and 6th Avenue on the left.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

text:
Rockefeller Plaza, at the N.W. corner of West 49th Street (left), showing the R. C. A. Building gardens.

April 24, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)

folder: 14 West 49th Street - 1 Rockefeller Plaza, Manhattan, NY
title: 14 West 49th Street - 1 Rockefeller Plaza

text:
Rockefeller Plaza - W. 48th to 51st St.
RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, at night.
This interesting photograph shows the 70-story RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, New York City, flood-lighted. In the foreground may be seen the Prometheus Fountain in the Sunken Plaza directly in front of the RCA Building.
From: Rockefeller Center, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, N.Y.
Photographer: Wendell MacRae, 1270 Sixth Ave., Rockefeller Center, New York City
title: Manhattan: Rockefeller Plaza - 49th Street (West)
